moves.1. d4: queen pawn, but just to change the order...
moves.1... Nf6 2. c4: ... cause good old english is back, by reversed moves
moves.8... dxc4: pointing my good knight fellow on the right side of the board...
moves.10. a3: well, where will you put your bishop?
moves.10... cxd4: er... nowhere, I attack your stupid knight... The other one, i mean.
moves.11. Nxd4: i Have considered axb dxc, but after exd Qxd4, I see doubled pawns and no advantage for white.
moves.11... Bc5 12. Nb3 Nbd7 13. Qe2 Qc7: both queens try to find safer place, and prepare for an attack (mostly black queen).
moves.14... Nxc5: better than to take with pawns, but now c and d columns are largely opened for rooks.
moves.15. Rac1: and... here we go. (and conscious of eventual Nb3)
moves.16... Nd5 17. Nxd5 exd5: I had the feeling that black wanted the draw, here.
moves.18. Bb5 Qd6: of course not Qc7 or c8, because of the next move...
moves.19. b4 Ne6 20. Rc2 a6 21. Ba4 b5: this manoeuvre just helped me to comfort my bishops focusing on both the center and the king, as we'll see. I recognize that black helped me a lot here.
moves.22. Bb3: Here we go, pointing o weak pawn!
moves.22... Rfe8: I wonder how valuable would have been d4, here.
moves.25. Rd1: and now d4 is no more an option...
moves.25... Qe7 26. a4 Qg5: black is deeply focused on my king, but there is nothing serious as the line 2 is well defended.
moves.28. h4 Qg6 29. Rcd2: focusing on the central weak pawn.
moves.30. e4: of course, dxe is impossible, as it is followed by Rxd8. This move is the first one which included the next ones I planned. Before that, I had no clear idea how to penetrate. I only had the idea to focus on the weak pawn.
moves.30... Rd7 31. Kh2: this prepares the next, which i hoped to be a surprised for my opponent... The computer did not like this movement, and prefer to take the weak pawn directly, but this convert my strong pawn in weak pawn... So i don't like the computer option.
moves.31... Red8 32. e5: and... I think it was a surprise, as we'll see.
moves.32... Qe6 33. f4: now 2 pawns, very strong are going to treasure land...
moves.33... Qf5: black seems without idea. Why black queen didn't go there first? And why go there?
moves.35. f5: e and f pawns makes black queen play... In the meanwhile, black bishop and knight are blocked... no speaking of the rooks... On the other side, both of my bishops threat the king-side
moves.35... Qc6 36. Qg3: threatening discovered attacks on the king AND protecting g2.
moves.36... Ne8: decent move... but will lead to a larger blockade.
moves.37. Bd4: prohibiting the e4 advancing, but also threatening another move... do you see which one?
moves.37... Ba8: does not know what to play... can't blame him... black has no more space.
moves.38. h5: if i had played f6, I guess black would have played g6, and the threat was almost killed. So i had to prohibate it.
moves.38... f6: once again, black had no choice: f6 played by white was too dangerous.
moves.39... Re7 40. Bb3:
3 reasons for this move: it liberates my rook for bishop protection; it opens my light bishop to better attack position, as previous diagonal was no more productive. Could sayt also that, in case the attack does not conclude on d column, I have a new perspective on c-column... but black has counter-game in that case.

the computer suggests this is a mistake (without jeopardize the victory, though), and prefer the direct attack on the rooks by Bc5
moves.40... Rc8: pointless. I was amazed to see this move.
moves.41. Bc5: and here is the very decisive positioning move. My bishops were really strong
moves.41... Rec7 42. Rd2xd5:
finally the weak pawn is taken... but it was no more the target, only an obstacle for next moves.
Computer estimates this is a blunder, but I am really not convinced by its point of view...
moves.42... Qa6: weak counter-attack... but was it possible to respond to next attack?
moves.43... Rxd8: maybe better was to play 43 ... Qc6 but then 44 Bd5 followed by a lot of exchange: ... Rxd8 45 Bxc6 Rxd1 (and my king on h2 makes sense) 46 Bxa8 => White gains Q+B>< R+R, with the bonus of e6 very strong. But still black option here is a disaster
moves.44. Rxd8: the king can't defend the knight... so, the only "defense" is:
moves.44... Rc8 45. e7+: but now the rook is too well defended. And a discovered check that forced the end.
moves.45... Kh8 46. Qg6:
46. ... Qc6 47 Bd5  (not Qf7 of course, that would be followed by Qxg2x) Qxd5 48 Qxe8+ Qg8 49 Qxg8x or Kh7 49 Qh8x
Thanks for having read these until the end. I hope you enjoyed as much as I did.
